bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to Edward Tucker, September 2, 1728

div1.p: Robert Carter writes to Weymouth merchant Edward Tucker, September 2, 1728, to give the merchant early notice of a bill ofo exchange that he has drawn payable to John Tayloe.

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to Edward Tucker, September 2, 1728

opener.dateline:
Rappahannock, [Lancaster County, Virginia]
Sepr. 2d. 1728
Edward Tucker Esqr.

div1.p:
I writ to you the other day by an Exeter man
it was quite out of my thoughts to advise you of a bill of Exchange I
had drawn upon you to Colonel John Tayloe for £30"10. The Ship I
bought the Slaves out of by whom the bills were to go is not yet come
down our river however it is necessary to be early with my advice
Capt. Willson I hope is got near you by this time I took my leave
of him the 23d. of July I am.

closer.seg:
Sir
Yor. most humble Servt.
per Dunlop

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Letter book, 1728 August-1731 July, Robert Carter Papers (acc. no. 3807), Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia.

Robert Carter generally used a return address of "Rappahannock" for the river on which he lived rather than "Corotoman," the name of his home, on his correspondence, especially to merchants abroad. The county and colony have been added for clarity.

[1] John Tayloe (1687-1747) of Mt. Airy, Richmond County, who served as justice, burgess, colonel of militia, and as a member of the Council after 1732. (Ryland. Richmond County Virginia. . . . pp. 115-16.)
[3] A Captain Wilson is mentioned in Carter's letter to Edward Tucker of 1721 May 27 as having arrived after "15 weeks passage." and in his 1723 diary.
[4] The Martha was commanded by a Captain Dunlop; see Carter to Richard Oswald & Company 1729 August 11.
